description: From Middle English tractable, tractabel, from Latin tractābilis (“that may be touched, handled, or managed”), from tractō (“take in hand, handle, manage”), frequentative of trahō (“draw”).

adjectives.description: tractable (comparative more tractable, superlative most tractable)

entries.meaning: (of people) Capable of being easily led, taught, or managed.
(of a problem) Easy to deal with or manage

examples: I need not point out the advantages of modelling in a material as durable as stone. . . . Mixed up with just enough water to form a stiff paste, it accommodates itself to the touch of the modelling tool. . . . There are two inherent difficulties in using it—one, it is not so tractable as clay. . . .

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Capable of being handled or touched.
(mathematics) Sufficiently operationalizable or useful to allow a mathematical calculation to proceed toward a solution.
examples: This assumption is in the Raiffa and Schlaifer (1961, p. 72) spirit of using ‘a little ingenuity. . . to find a tractable function’ to quantify risk-preferences and probability judgments so as to make the analysis feasible.

entries.meaning: (computer science, of a decision problem) Algorithmically solvable fast enough to be practically relevant, typically in polynomial time.
